Blurb
Overview
Building upon the core concepts from BIOS101, this module describes the embryology, development, function (animal, both invertebrate and vertebrate, including humans), and dysfunction using a systems approach.
This modules describes the processes of early embryology through to system development from their primary germ call layers to their normal physiology in a range of animals, not forgetting examples of key pathophysiologies.
This module also provides the opportunity for students to: develop their understanding of key areas of pharmacology, infection, immunity, and therapeutics; to appreciate and understand the similarities and differences in development and function of similar systems. All of which aid in the development and enhancement of our functional biology knowledge, providing a suitable platform upon which to build any of our suite of degree programmes. A mix of learning modes will be used in this module which will include, but not be limited to, lectures, workshops, seminars, and the use of directed reading/multimedia.

There are THREE assessments. This module will be assessed by two in-course assessments, scheduled outside of the School of Life Sciences two cycle assessment strategy. The assessment schedule for this module will be as follows:

Assessment 1 (15% of module) - comprised of mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching item questions
Assessment 2 (15% of module) - comprised of mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching item questions
Assessment 3 (70% of module) - an end of module assessment which is split into THREE parts:
- Part A which will be a similar format to assessment 1 and 2 on this module,
- Part B which will comprise a schematic/ figure interpretation exercises.
- Part C which will comprise a comprehension/ data interpretation exercises.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

• To foster in students an appreciation and understanding of the fundamental principles of germ layer formation and organogenesis, organ/systems physiology, and comparative animal physiology.

• To foster in students an appreciation and understanding of the fundamental principles of infection, immunity, and pharmacology.

• To enable students to apply and interpret this knowledge to solve problems both in the wider context of biology and the respective biological disciplines.
Marketing Module Synopsis
In this module students will study in three blocks, the first is embryology and development of organ systems. The students will then continue to develop their knowledge of organ function in invertebrate and vertebrate animals (including humans) and compare these with organisms who have adapted their function to meet the challenges of a range of environments, in the second block. This approach has been taken to aid in our understanding of organ function from its commonalities to its varied differences. A cellular & molecular approach is used as students focus on the control, regulation, development and function of organs, organ systems & organisms. The third and final block has a focus on infection, immunity and microbial diversity.

The overall aim of this module is to facilitate the study of how cells develop and work together to form functional tissues and organs, and how this is imperative to the normal functioning of organisms and their adaptation, response and defence mechanisms.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures and workshops, which will be supported with directed learning resources (reading/ multimedia).

There are three assessments. This module will be assessed by two in-course assessments, scheduled outside of the School of Life Sciences two cycle assessment strategy and an end of module exam.
Outline Syllabus
Block 1:

Introductions to Reproduction, Embryology and Development.

Interaction with the external environment.

Communication, control, and maintenance of the internal environment, from macro to micro to molecular levels.

Introductions to muscle, movement, and sensory systems in mammals (humans) and a range of comparative animal examples.

Introductions to Nociception and analgesia and associated Pharmacology of drug delivery, absorption, and distribution.


Block 2:

Development and function of physiological systems, from macro to micro to molecular levels in invertebrate and vertebrate animals (including humans) and a range of comparative animal examples.

Systems could include, but will not be limited to, Cardiorespiratory, Digestive, Excretion and Osmoregulation (Renal), and Hepatic.

An introduction to pharmacokinetics including but not limited to drug metabolism and elimination.


Block 3:

Introduction to core concepts in Immunity and infection.

Development and function of the immune system, from macro to micro to molecular levels in invertebrate and vertebrate animals (including humans) and a range of comparative animal examples.

Introduction to the microbiology of agents of infectious disease.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Online Preparatory Material:  

This is in the form of online reading, multimedia and small tasks to introduce key concepts and prepares students for the block of upcoming lectures.  

Lectures:  

The module will be taught through lectures with an emphasis towards active learning as detailed below. These will cover the core module content and characterised by interactive group discussions and activities to enhance understanding of key concepts. 63 x 1 hour Teaching Sessions will be delivered over an eight-week period.  

Guided workshops: These will provide opportunities for students to work through formative assessment examples in the weeks which have summative assessments.

Independent learning: Each teaching session will be accompanied by approx. 2 hours of independent study from online resources and texts, and it is expected that this learning is consolidated by 100 hours of independent learning that integrates material across the course. Encompasses all unscheduled learning activities, e.g., directed reading, use of multimedia, self-directed learning, in preparation for lectures, revision study and work towards assessment.

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways: 

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active/ connected scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Comprehension and data interpretation assessments will provide opportunities for students to provide evidence-based responses from their exploration of secondary sources.  

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. 

Active learning: Opportunities for interactive structured participation will be provided, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, Kahoot) and collaborative, interactive tools (e.g. Padlet, Miro). Formative feedback opportunities (e.g. Peer learning assessment, comparative judgement analysis, and quizzes) will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.  These opportunities will be available in taught sessions and self directed learning, using online platforms.

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment strategies. Data interpretation is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. The online tests require students to lead their own enquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base which will be applied to subsequent modules. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning. 

Confidence: This is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.  

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology. 

Global citizenship: Organisms, their development, their varied physiology, and immunity, infection, and therapeutics are studied at a global scale. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities.  

Attendance recoded: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Formative feedback opportunities (e.g. Peer learning assessment, comparative judgement analysis, and quizzes) will provide students with regular feedback on their learning. These opportunities will be available in taught sessions and self directed learning, using online platforms.

Summative assessments at regular intervals throughout the course. We expect two open book online summative assessments (30%), one for each block, and a final data recognition and interpretation unseen exam at the end of the module (70%).

Coursework Assessment 1 - Mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching answer questions covering the materials from the Block 1 section (30 sessions) of this module (15% total)

Coursework Assessment 2 - Mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching answer questions covering the materials from the Block 2 section (21 sessions) of this module (15% total)

Final Assessment 3 - End of module assessment, comprising THREE components:

Part A, a mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching answer questions covering the materials from the Block 3 section (12 sessions) of this module (10%).
Part B, Mixed multiple choice, multiple answer schematics/ figure interpretation covering materials from all sections of the module (20%)
Part C, a comprehension/ data interpretation exercise in which, for example, a recent publication or data set relating to the module topics is provided to students, who then are expected to answer short answer questions on its content, interpret the data within and, for example, predict scenario outcomes or plan onward research. (40%)

The data interpretation assessment is highly authentic and research-connected, and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. (Active learning, digital fluency, confidence - Liverpool Curriculum Framework). 

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Blurb
Overview
Building upon the core concepts from BIOS101, this module describes the embryology, development, function (animal, both invertebrate and vertebrate, including humans), and dysfunction using a systems approach.
This modules describes the processes of early embryology through to system development from their primary germ call layers to their normal physiology in a range of animals, not forgetting examples of key pathophysiologies.
This module also provides the opportunity for students to: develop their understanding of key areas of pharmacology, infection, immunity, and therapeutics; to appreciate and understand the similarities and differences in development and function of similar systems. All of which aid in the development and enhancement of our functional biology knowledge, providing a suitable platform upon which to build any of our suite of degree programmes. A mix of learning modes will be used in this module which will include, but not be limited to, lectures, workshops, seminars, and the use of directed reading/multimedia.

There are THREE assessments. This module will be assessed by two in-course assessments, scheduled outside of the School of Life Sciences two cycle assessment strategy. The assessment schedule for this module will be as follows:

Assessment 1 (15% of module) - comprised of mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching item questions
Assessment 2 (15% of module) - comprised of mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching item questions
Assessment 3 (70% of module) - an end of module assessment which is split into THREE parts:
- Part A which will be a similar format to assessment 1 and 2 on this module,
- Part B which will comprise a schematic/ figure interpretation exercises.
- Part C which will comprise a comprehension/ data interpretation exercises.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

• To foster in students an appreciation and understanding of the fundamental principles of germ layer formation and organogenesis, organ/systems physiology, and comparative animal physiology.

• To foster in students an appreciation and understanding of the fundamental principles of infection, immunity, and pharmacology.

• To enable students to apply and interpret this knowledge to solve problems both in the wider context of biology and the respective biological disciplines.
Marketing Module Synopsis
In this module students will study in three blocks, the first is embryology and development of organ systems. The students will then continue to develop their knowledge of organ function in invertebrate and vertebrate animals (including humans) and compare these with organisms who have adapted their function to meet the challenges of a range of environments, in the second block. This approach has been taken to aid in our understanding of organ function from its commonalities to its varied differences. A cellular & molecular approach is used as students focus on the control, regulation, development and function of organs, organ systems & organisms. The third and final block has a focus on infection, immunity and microbial diversity.

The overall aim of this module is to facilitate the study of how cells develop and work together to form functional tissues and organs, and how this is imperative to the normal functioning of organisms and their adaptation, response and defence mechanisms.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures and workshops, which will be supported with directed learning resources (reading/ multimedia).

There are three assessments. This module will be assessed by two in-course assessments, scheduled outside of the School of Life Sciences two cycle assessment strategy and an end of module exam.
Outline Syllabus
Block 1:

Introductions to Reproduction, Embryology and Development.

Interaction with the external environment.

Communication, control, and maintenance of the internal environment, from macro to micro to molecular levels.

Introductions to muscle, movement, and sensory systems in mammals (humans) and a range of comparative animal examples.

Introductions to Nociception and analgesia and associated Pharmacology of drug delivery, absorption, and distribution.


Block 2:

Development and function of physiological systems, from macro to micro to molecular levels in invertebrate and vertebrate animals (including humans) and a range of comparative animal examples.

Systems could include, but will not be limited to, Cardiorespiratory, Digestive, Excretion and Osmoregulation (Renal), and Hepatic.

An introduction to pharmacokinetics including but not limited to drug metabolism and elimination.


Block 3:

Introduction to core concepts in Immunity and infection.

Development and function of the immune system, from macro to micro to molecular levels in invertebrate and vertebrate animals (including humans) and a range of comparative animal examples.

Introduction to the microbiology of agents of infectious disease.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Online Preparatory Material:  

This is in the form of online reading, multimedia and small tasks to introduce key concepts and prepares students for the block of upcoming lectures.  

Lectures:  

The module will be taught through lectures with an emphasis towards active learning as detailed below. These will cover the core module content and characterised by interactive group discussions and activities to enhance understanding of key concepts. 63 x 1 hour Teaching Sessions will be delivered over an eight-week period.  

Guided workshops: These will provide opportunities for students to work through formative assessment examples in the weeks which have summative assessments.

Independent learning: Each teaching session will be accompanied by approx. 2 hours of independent study from online resources and texts, and it is expected that this learning is consolidated by 100 hours of independent learning that integrates material across the course. Encompasses all unscheduled learning activities, e.g., directed reading, use of multimedia, self-directed learning, in preparation for lectures, revision study and work towards assessment.

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways: 

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active/ connected scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Comprehension and data interpretation assessments will provide opportunities for students to provide evidence-based responses from their exploration of secondary sources.  

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. 

Active learning: Opportunities for interactive structured participation will be provided, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, Kahoot) and collaborative, interactive tools (e.g. Padlet, Miro). Formative feedback opportunities (e.g. Peer learning assessment, comparative judgement analysis, and quizzes) will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.  These opportunities will be available in taught sessions and self directed learning, using online platforms.

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment strategies. Data interpretation is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. The online tests require students to lead their own enquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base which will be applied to subsequent modules. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning. 

Confidence: This is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.  

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology. 

Global citizenship: Organisms, their development, their varied physiology, and immunity, infection, and therapeutics are studied at a global scale. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities.  

Attendance recoded: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Formative feedback opportunities (e.g. Peer learning assessment, comparative judgement analysis, and quizzes) will provide students with regular feedback on their learning. These opportunities will be available in taught sessions and self directed learning, using online platforms.

Summative assessments at regular intervals throughout the course. We expect two open book online summative assessments (30%), one for each block, and a final data recognition and interpretation unseen exam at the end of the module (70%).

Coursework Assessment 1 - Mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching answer questions covering the materials from the Block 1 section (30 sessions) of this module (15% total)

Coursework Assessment 2 - Mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching answer questions covering the materials from the Block 2 section (21 sessions) of this module (15% total)

Final Assessment 3 - End of module assessment, comprising THREE components:

Part A, a mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching answer questions covering the materials from the Block 3 section (12 sessions) of this module (10%).
Part B, Mixed multiple choice, multiple answer schematics/ figure interpretation covering materials from all sections of the module (20%)
Part C, a comprehension/ data interpretation exercise in which, for example, a recent publication or data set relating to the module topics is provided to students, who then are expected to answer short answer questions on its content, interpret the data within and, for example, predict scenario outcomes or plan onward research. (40%)

The data interpretation assessment is highly authentic and research-connected, and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. (Active learning, digital fluency, confidence - Liverpool Curriculum Framework). 

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Blurb
Overview
Building upon the core concepts from BIOS101, this module describes the embryology, development, function (animal, both invertebrate and vertebrate, including humans), and dysfunction using a systems approach.
This modules describes the processes of early embryology through to system development from their primary germ call layers to their normal physiology in a range of animals, not forgetting examples of key pathophysiologies.
This module also provides the opportunity for students to: develop their understanding of key areas of pharmacology, infection, immunity, and therapeutics; to appreciate and understand the similarities and differences in development and function of similar systems. All of which aid in the development and enhancement of our functional biology knowledge, providing a suitable platform upon which to build any of our suite of degree programmes. A mix of learning modes will be used in this module which will include, but not be limited to, lectures, workshops, seminars, and the use of directed reading/multimedia.

There are THREE assessments. This module will be assessed by two in-course assessments, scheduled outside of the School of Life Sciences two cycle assessment strategy. The assessment schedule for this module will be as follows:

Assessment 1 (15% of module) - comprised of mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching item questions
Assessment 2 (15% of module) - comprised of mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching item questions
Assessment 3 (70% of module) - an end of module assessment which is split into THREE parts:
- Part A which will be a similar format to assessment 1 and 2 on this module,
- Part B which will comprise a schematic/ figure interpretation exercises.
- Part C which will comprise a comprehension/ data interpretation exercises.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

• To foster in students an appreciation and understanding of the fundamental principles of germ layer formation and organogenesis, organ/systems physiology, and comparative animal physiology.

• To foster in students an appreciation and understanding of the fundamental principles of infection, immunity, and pharmacology.

• To enable students to apply and interpret this knowledge to solve problems both in the wider context of biology and the respective biological disciplines.
Marketing Module Synopsis
In this module students will study in three blocks, the first is embryology and development of organ systems. The students will then continue to develop their knowledge of organ function in invertebrate and vertebrate animals (including humans) and compare these with organisms who have adapted their function to meet the challenges of a range of environments, in the second block. This approach has been taken to aid in our understanding of organ function from its commonalities to its varied differences. A cellular & molecular approach is used as students focus on the control, regulation, development and function of organs, organ systems & organisms. The third and final block has a focus on infection, immunity and microbial diversity.

The overall aim of this module is to facilitate the study of how cells develop and work together to form functional tissues and organs, and how this is imperative to the normal functioning of organisms and their adaptation, response and defence mechanisms.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures and workshops, which will be supported with directed learning resources (reading/ multimedia).

There are three assessments. This module will be assessed by two in-course assessments, scheduled outside of the School of Life Sciences two cycle assessment strategy and an end of module exam.
Outline Syllabus
Block 1:

Introductions to Reproduction, Embryology and Development.

Interaction with the external environment.

Communication, control, and maintenance of the internal environment, from macro to micro to molecular levels.

Introductions to muscle, movement, and sensory systems in mammals (humans) and a range of comparative animal examples.

Introductions to Nociception and analgesia and associated Pharmacology of drug delivery, absorption, and distribution.


Block 2:

Development and function of physiological systems, from macro to micro to molecular levels in invertebrate and vertebrate animals (including humans) and a range of comparative animal examples.

Systems could include, but will not be limited to, Cardiorespiratory, Digestive, Excretion and Osmoregulation (Renal), and Hepatic.

An introduction to pharmacokinetics including but not limited to drug metabolism and elimination.


Block 3:

Introduction to core concepts in Immunity and infection.

Development and function of the immune system, from macro to micro to molecular levels in invertebrate and vertebrate animals (including humans) and a range of comparative animal examples.

Introduction to the microbiology of agents of infectious disease.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Online Preparatory Material:  

This is in the form of online reading, multimedia and small tasks to introduce key concepts and prepares students for the block of upcoming lectures.  

Lectures:  

The module will be taught through lectures with an emphasis towards active learning as detailed below. These will cover the core module content and characterised by interactive group discussions and activities to enhance understanding of key concepts. 63 x 1 hour Teaching Sessions will be delivered over an eight-week period.  

Guided workshops: These will provide opportunities for students to work through formative assessment examples in the weeks which have summative assessments.

Independent learning: Each teaching session will be accompanied by approx. 2 hours of independent study from online resources and texts, and it is expected that this learning is consolidated by 100 hours of independent learning that integrates material across the course. Encompasses all unscheduled learning activities, e.g., directed reading, use of multimedia, self-directed learning, in preparation for lectures, revision study and work towards assessment.

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways: 

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active/ connected scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Comprehension and data interpretation assessments will provide opportunities for students to provide evidence-based responses from their exploration of secondary sources.  

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. 

Active learning: Opportunities for interactive structured participation will be provided, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, Kahoot) and collaborative, interactive tools (e.g. Padlet, Miro). Formative feedback opportunities (e.g. Peer learning assessment, comparative judgement analysis, and quizzes) will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.  These opportunities will be available in taught sessions and self directed learning, using online platforms.

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment strategies. Data interpretation is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. The online tests require students to lead their own enquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base which will be applied to subsequent modules. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning. 

Confidence: This is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.  

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology. 

Global citizenship: Organisms, their development, their varied physiology, and immunity, infection, and therapeutics are studied at a global scale. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities.  

Attendance recoded: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Formative feedback opportunities (e.g. Peer learning assessment, comparative judgement analysis, and quizzes) will provide students with regular feedback on their learning. These opportunities will be available in taught sessions and self directed learning, using online platforms.

Summative assessments at regular intervals throughout the course. We expect two open book online summative assessments (30%), one for each block, and a final data recognition and interpretation unseen exam at the end of the module (70%).

Coursework Assessment 1 - Mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching answer questions covering the materials from the Block 1 section (30 sessions) of this module (15% total)

Coursework Assessment 2 - Mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching answer questions covering the materials from the Block 2 section (21 sessions) of this module (15% total)

Final Assessment 3 - End of module assessment, comprising THREE components:

Part A, a mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching answer questions covering the materials from the Block 3 section (12 sessions) of this module (10%).
Part B, Mixed multiple choice, multiple answer schematics/ figure interpretation covering materials from all sections of the module (20%)
Part C, a comprehension/ data interpretation exercise in which, for example, a recent publication or data set relating to the module topics is provided to students, who then are expected to answer short answer questions on its content, interpret the data within and, for example, predict scenario outcomes or plan onward research. (40%)

The data interpretation assessment is highly authentic and research-connected, and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. (Active learning, digital fluency, confidence - Liverpool Curriculum Framework). 

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Blurb
Overview
Building upon the core concepts from BIOS101, this module describes the embryology, development, function (animal, both invertebrate and vertebrate, including humans), and dysfunction using a systems approach.
This modules describes the processes of early embryology through to system development from their primary germ call layers to their normal physiology in a range of animals, not forgetting examples of key pathophysiologies.
This module also provides the opportunity for students to: develop their understanding of key areas of pharmacology, infection, immunity, and therapeutics; to appreciate and understand the similarities and differences in development and function of similar systems. All of which aid in the development and enhancement of our functional biology knowledge, providing a suitable platform upon which to build any of our suite of degree programmes. A mix of learning modes will be used in this module which will include, but not be limited to, lectures, workshops, seminars, and the use of directed reading/multimedia.

There are THREE assessments. This module will be assessed by two in-course assessments, scheduled outside of the School of Life Sciences two cycle assessment strategy. The assessment schedule for this module will be as follows:

Assessment 1 (15% of module) - comprised of mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching item questions
Assessment 2 (15% of module) - comprised of mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching item questions
Assessment 3 (70% of module) - an end of module assessment which is split into THREE parts:
- Part A which will be a similar format to assessment 1 and 2 on this module,
- Part B which will comprise a schematic/ figure interpretation exercises.
- Part C which will comprise a comprehension/ data interpretation exercises.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

• To foster in students an appreciation and understanding of the fundamental principles of germ layer formation and organogenesis, organ/systems physiology, and comparative animal physiology.

• To foster in students an appreciation and understanding of the fundamental principles of infection, immunity, and pharmacology.

• To enable students to apply and interpret this knowledge to solve problems both in the wider context of biology and the respective biological disciplines.
Marketing Module Synopsis
In this module students will study in three blocks, the first is embryology and development of organ systems. The students will then continue to develop their knowledge of organ function in invertebrate and vertebrate animals (including humans) and compare these with organisms who have adapted their function to meet the challenges of a range of environments, in the second block. This approach has been taken to aid in our understanding of organ function from its commonalities to its varied differences. A cellular & molecular approach is used as students focus on the control, regulation, development and function of organs, organ systems & organisms. The third and final block has a focus on infection, immunity and microbial diversity.

The overall aim of this module is to facilitate the study of how cells develop and work together to form functional tissues and organs, and how this is imperative to the normal functioning of organisms and their adaptation, response and defence mechanisms.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures and workshops, which will be supported with directed learning resources (reading/ multimedia).

There are three assessments. This module will be assessed by two in-course assessments, scheduled outside of the School of Life Sciences two cycle assessment strategy and an end of module exam.
Outline Syllabus
Block 1:

Introductions to Reproduction, Embryology and Development.

Interaction with the external environment.

Communication, control, and maintenance of the internal environment, from macro to micro to molecular levels.

Introductions to muscle, movement, and sensory systems in mammals (humans) and a range of comparative animal examples.

Introductions to Nociception and analgesia and associated Pharmacology of drug delivery, absorption, and distribution.


Block 2:

Development and function of physiological systems, from macro to micro to molecular levels in invertebrate and vertebrate animals (including humans) and a range of comparative animal examples.

Systems could include, but will not be limited to, Cardiorespiratory, Digestive, Excretion and Osmoregulation (Renal), and Hepatic.

An introduction to pharmacokinetics including but not limited to drug metabolism and elimination.


Block 3:

Introduction to core concepts in Immunity and infection.

Development and function of the immune system, from macro to micro to molecular levels in invertebrate and vertebrate animals (including humans) and a range of comparative animal examples.

Introduction to the microbiology of agents of infectious disease.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Online Preparatory Material:  

This is in the form of online reading, multimedia and small tasks to introduce key concepts and prepares students for the block of upcoming lectures.  

Lectures:  

The module will be taught through lectures with an emphasis towards active learning as detailed below. These will cover the core module content and characterised by interactive group discussions and activities to enhance understanding of key concepts. 63 x 1 hour Teaching Sessions will be delivered over an eight-week period.  

Guided workshops: These will provide opportunities for students to work through formative assessment examples in the weeks which have summative assessments.

Independent learning: Each teaching session will be accompanied by approx. 2 hours of independent study from online resources and texts, and it is expected that this learning is consolidated by 100 hours of independent learning that integrates material across the course. Encompasses all unscheduled learning activities, e.g., directed reading, use of multimedia, self-directed learning, in preparation for lectures, revision study and work towards assessment.

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways: 

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active/ connected scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Comprehension and data interpretation assessments will provide opportunities for students to provide evidence-based responses from their exploration of secondary sources.  

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. 

Active learning: Opportunities for interactive structured participation will be provided, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, Kahoot) and collaborative, interactive tools (e.g. Padlet, Miro). Formative feedback opportunities (e.g. Peer learning assessment, comparative judgement analysis, and quizzes) will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.  These opportunities will be available in taught sessions and self directed learning, using online platforms.

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment strategies. Data interpretation is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. The online tests require students to lead their own enquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base which will be applied to subsequent modules. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning. 

Confidence: This is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.  

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology. 

Global citizenship: Organisms, their development, their varied physiology, and immunity, infection, and therapeutics are studied at a global scale. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities.  

Attendance recoded: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Formative feedback opportunities (e.g. Peer learning assessment, comparative judgement analysis, and quizzes) will provide students with regular feedback on their learning. These opportunities will be available in taught sessions and self directed learning, using online platforms.

Summative assessments at regular intervals throughout the course. We expect two open book online summative assessments (30%), one for each block, and a final data recognition and interpretation unseen exam at the end of the module (70%).

Coursework Assessment 1 - Mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching answer questions covering the materials from the Block 1 section (30 sessions) of this module (15% total)

Coursework Assessment 2 - Mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching answer questions covering the materials from the Block 2 section (21 sessions) of this module (15% total)

Final Assessment 3 - End of module assessment, comprising THREE components:

Part A, a mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching answer questions covering the materials from the Block 3 section (12 sessions) of this module (10%).
Part B, Mixed multiple choice, multiple answer schematics/ figure interpretation covering materials from all sections of the module (20%)
Part C, a comprehension/ data interpretation exercise in which, for example, a recent publication or data set relating to the module topics is provided to students, who then are expected to answer short answer questions on its content, interpret the data within and, for example, predict scenario outcomes or plan onward research. (40%)

The data interpretation assessment is highly authentic and research-connected, and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. (Active learning, digital fluency, confidence - Liverpool Curriculum Framework). 

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Blurb
Overview
Building upon the core concepts from BIOS101, this module describes the embryology, development, function (animal, both invertebrate and vertebrate, including humans), and dysfunction using a systems approach.
This modules describes the processes of early embryology through to system development from their primary germ call layers to their normal physiology in a range of animals, not forgetting examples of key pathophysiologies.
This module also provides the opportunity for students to: develop their understanding of key areas of pharmacology, infection, immunity, and therapeutics; to appreciate and understand the similarities and differences in development and function of similar systems. All of which aid in the development and enhancement of our functional biology knowledge, providing a suitable platform upon which to build any of our suite of degree programmes. A mix of learning modes will be used in this module which will include, but not be limited to, lectures, workshops, seminars, and the use of directed reading/multimedia.

There are THREE assessments. This module will be assessed by two in-course assessments, scheduled outside of the School of Life Sciences two cycle assessment strategy. The assessment schedule for this module will be as follows:

Assessment 1 (15% of module) - comprised of mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching item questions
Assessment 2 (15% of module) - comprised of mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching item questions
Assessment 3 (70% of module) - an end of module assessment which is split into THREE parts:
- Part A which will be a similar format to assessment 1 and 2 on this module,
- Part B which will comprise a schematic/ figure interpretation exercises.
- Part C which will comprise a comprehension/ data interpretation exercises.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

• To foster in students an appreciation and understanding of the fundamental principles of germ layer formation and organogenesis, organ/systems physiology, and comparative animal physiology.

• To foster in students an appreciation and understanding of the fundamental principles of infection, immunity, and pharmacology.

• To enable students to apply and interpret this knowledge to solve problems both in the wider context of biology and the respective biological disciplines.
Marketing Module Synopsis
In this module students will study in three blocks, the first is embryology and development of organ systems. The students will then continue to develop their knowledge of organ function in invertebrate and vertebrate animals (including humans) and compare these with organisms who have adapted their function to meet the challenges of a range of environments, in the second block. This approach has been taken to aid in our understanding of organ function from its commonalities to its varied differences. A cellular & molecular approach is used as students focus on the control, regulation, development and function of organs, organ systems & organisms. The third and final block has a focus on infection, immunity and microbial diversity.

The overall aim of this module is to facilitate the study of how cells develop and work together to form functional tissues and organs, and how this is imperative to the normal functioning of organisms and their adaptation, response and defence mechanisms.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures and workshops, which will be supported with directed learning resources (reading/ multimedia).

There are three assessments. This module will be assessed by two in-course assessments, scheduled outside of the School of Life Sciences two cycle assessment strategy and an end of module exam.
Outline Syllabus
Block 1:

Introductions to Reproduction, Embryology and Development.

Interaction with the external environment.

Communication, control, and maintenance of the internal environment, from macro to micro to molecular levels.

Introductions to muscle, movement, and sensory systems in mammals (humans) and a range of comparative animal examples.

Introductions to Nociception and analgesia and associated Pharmacology of drug delivery, absorption, and distribution.


Block 2:

Development and function of physiological systems, from macro to micro to molecular levels in invertebrate and vertebrate animals (including humans) and a range of comparative animal examples.

Systems could include, but will not be limited to, Cardiorespiratory, Digestive, Excretion and Osmoregulation (Renal), and Hepatic.

An introduction to pharmacokinetics including but not limited to drug metabolism and elimination.


Block 3:

Introduction to core concepts in Immunity and infection.

Development and function of the immune system, from macro to micro to molecular levels in invertebrate and vertebrate animals (including humans) and a range of comparative animal examples.

Introduction to the microbiology of agents of infectious disease.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Online Preparatory Material:  

This is in the form of online reading, multimedia and small tasks to introduce key concepts and prepares students for the block of upcoming lectures.  

Lectures:  

The module will be taught through lectures with an emphasis towards active learning as detailed below. These will cover the core module content and characterised by interactive group discussions and activities to enhance understanding of key concepts. 63 x 1 hour Teaching Sessions will be delivered over an eight-week period.  

Guided workshops: These will provide opportunities for students to work through formative assessment examples in the weeks which have summative assessments.

Independent learning: Each teaching session will be accompanied by approx. 2 hours of independent study from online resources and texts, and it is expected that this learning is consolidated by 100 hours of independent learning that integrates material across the course. Encompasses all unscheduled learning activities, e.g., directed reading, use of multimedia, self-directed learning, in preparation for lectures, revision study and work towards assessment.

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways: 

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active/ connected scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Comprehension and data interpretation assessments will provide opportunities for students to provide evidence-based responses from their exploration of secondary sources.  

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. 

Active learning: Opportunities for interactive structured participation will be provided, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, Kahoot) and collaborative, interactive tools (e.g. Padlet, Miro). Formative feedback opportunities (e.g. Peer learning assessment, comparative judgement analysis, and quizzes) will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.  These opportunities will be available in taught sessions and self directed learning, using online platforms.

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment strategies. Data interpretation is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. The online tests require students to lead their own enquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base which will be applied to subsequent modules. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning. 

Confidence: This is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.  

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology. 

Global citizenship: Organisms, their development, their varied physiology, and immunity, infection, and therapeutics are studied at a global scale. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities.  

Attendance recoded: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Formative feedback opportunities (e.g. Peer learning assessment, comparative judgement analysis, and quizzes) will provide students with regular feedback on their learning. These opportunities will be available in taught sessions and self directed learning, using online platforms.

Summative assessments at regular intervals throughout the course. We expect two open book online summative assessments (30%), one for each block, and a final data recognition and interpretation unseen exam at the end of the module (70%).

Coursework Assessment 1 - Mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching answer questions covering the materials from the Block 1 section (30 sessions) of this module (15% total)

Coursework Assessment 2 - Mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching answer questions covering the materials from the Block 2 section (21 sessions) of this module (15% total)

Final Assessment 3 - End of module assessment, comprising THREE components:

Part A, a mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching answer questions covering the materials from the Block 3 section (12 sessions) of this module (10%).
Part B, Mixed multiple choice, multiple answer schematics/ figure interpretation covering materials from all sections of the module (20%)
Part C, a comprehension/ data interpretation exercise in which, for example, a recent publication or data set relating to the module topics is provided to students, who then are expected to answer short answer questions on its content, interpret the data within and, for example, predict scenario outcomes or plan onward research. (40%)

The data interpretation assessment is highly authentic and research-connected, and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. (Active learning, digital fluency, confidence - Liverpool Curriculum Framework). 

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
